columns.text: In this problem, we will determine whether issuing new shares or repurchasing old ones are the better option based on the given conditions.

A share repurchase or buyback is done by a company when they re-buy their own shares from the market. This is typically done to increase the value of their company's stock in order to improve their financials structure. 

Another option that they can consider is to issue shares of their stock. This can help raise capital in order to bolster their financial structure to chase bigger projects or to help them pay debts.

**a.)** Here, we can start by first solving for the first case which is issuing new shares. When we issue new shares, it means that there will be an increase in the dividends that will be given out. To solve for this increase in dividend, we can simply take the given cost which is $\$17,500$ and divide it by the number of outstanding stocks.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Dividends per share}&=\dfrac{\$17,500}{2,000}\\[15 pt]
&=\$8.75
\end{aligned}$$

There will be a dividend of $\$8.75$ per share.

We can then subtract the dividend per share from the given share price of $\$64.00$ to get the new share price.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{New share price}&=\$64.00-\$8.75\\
&=\$55.25
\end{aligned}$$

This gives us a new share price of $\$55.25$

On the other hand, when repurchasing shares, the share price will remain the same since there is no additional dividends to be paid. 

Therefore, the price per share of the company's stock when repurchased is still at $\$64.00$.

This means that if the goal is to improve the financial structure without decreasing the value of the company's stock, the company should just **repurchase the shares** that are available in the market instead of issuing new stocks that will create an increase in the dividends.

**b.)** The EPS, or the earnings per share, of a company is basically the total earnings divided by the number of outstanding shares. 

For the first option of issuing more shares, it is given that the earnings per share is $\$1.89$.

However, for the second option, we can solve this by first solving for the number of shares that will be repurchased. This can be done by taking the cost and dividing it by the current price per share of the company.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Number of shares to be repurchased}&=\dfrac{\$17,500}{\$64.00}\\[15 pt]
&=273.44\\
&=273
\end{aligned}$$

The company should repurchase $\$273$ shares.

Now that we have the number of shares to be repurchased, this will be subtracted from the number of outstanding shares. 

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Number of outstanding shares}&=2,000-273\\
&=1,727
\end{aligned}$$

There will now be $1,727$ outstanding shares in the market.

For the price-earnings ratio (P/E), we can simply solve this by dividing the share price by the earnings per share.

For the first option of issuing more shares, the P/E ratio will be:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{P/E ratio}&=\dfrac{\$55.25}{\$1.89}\\[15 pt]
&=29.23
\end{aligned}$$

For the second option of repurchasing the shares, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{P/E ratio}&=\dfrac{\$64.00}{\$2.19}\\[15 pt]
&=29.22
\end{aligned}$$

As we can see here, the P/E ratio is practically the same for both options which indicates that the price of the shares and the earnings are proportional.

**c.)** Based on the given, it is more recommended to repurchase the shares since it gives higher earnings per share. Moreover, we can remember that issuing new shares have their own underlying cost which will make the earnings per share go down even more and thus create a P/E ratio that is lower. 

In the real world, it is then better to just repurchase the stock to reduce the possible cost and increase profitability to improve the financial structure of the company.
